For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config':     "output": "Thought:  \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201crydberg atom array\u201d and \u201centangled quantum state\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible target that emphasizes quantum networks rather than mere state generation:  \n  1) A chain of entanglement\u2010swapping steps linking four Rydberg\u2010array nodes (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D), all embedded in a single linear\u2010optical circuit, to entangle the end nodes A and D.  \n  2) A star\u2010network distribution: each of N Rydberg nodes emits photons that meet at a central station to implement a multi\u2010party swap protocol, distributing entanglement in a \u201chub\u2010and\u2010spoke\u201d fashion.  \n  3) A post\u2010selected multi-hop teleportation circuit: an unknown qubit prepared at node A is teleported through nodes B and C to arrive at node D, all via a single integrated beam\u2010splitter/measurement network.  \n\nStep 2: Quick novelty and Pytheus\u2010feasibility check:  \n  1) The 4-node chained swap (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D) is not in the existing list. It stays within entanglement\u2010swapping/quantum\u2010network paradigms, uses only single-photon emitters and beamsplitters, and needs no feedback control.  \n  2) The hub\u2010and-spoke star distribution edges toward GHZ/hyper-entanglement generation, which is closer to state generation.  \n  3) The multi-hop teleportation requires dynamic feed-forward corrections to recover the teleported state, which Pytheus cannot design.  \n\nStep 3: The 4-node chain of entanglement swaps is the most promising.  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus designs have concatenated two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping operations into one compact network to connect end nodes A and D across two intermediate Rydberg nodes B and C. Combining both swaps in a single circuit can reduce ancillary modes versus two isolated swap setups.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only demands:  \n  \u2022 single-photon emitters (modeling the Rydberg sites)  \n  \u2022 linear-optical mixing and post-selected photon counting  \n  \u2022 no feedback loops or cavities  \n  \u2022 a clear quantum-network task (two-hop entanglement swapping) rather than standalone state generation  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. Both the foundational entanglement\u2010swapping experiment (Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted) and its multi\u2010swap extensions (e.g. Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs, the \u201cbutterfly\u201d four\u2010photon joint measurement, or the one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeater) already cover this construction. As a trivial chain\u2010lengthening of known schemes, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening."

excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Therefore the corresponding value is [0, 1] as the photons 0 and 1 (making up the final 3d Bell state) should have no common source\\n\\nThe ancillary particles are measured by a third party, similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits).\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two particles with dimensionality four.', 'foldername': '4d-ES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 20, 'ftol': 1e-05, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22', '33'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.2, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 1]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': True, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. It stays within entanglement\u2010swapping/quantum\u2010network paradigms, uses only single-photon emitters and beamsplitters, and needs no feedback control.  \n  2) The hub\u2010and-spoke star distribution edges toward GHZ/hyper-entanglement generation, which is closer to state generation.  \n  3) The multi-hop teleportation requires dynamic feed-forward corrections to recover the teleported state, which Pytheus cannot design.  \n\nStep 3: The 4-node chain of entanglement swaps is the most promising.  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus designs have concatenated two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping operations into one compact network to connect end nodes A and D across two intermediate Rydberg nodes B and C. Combining both swaps in a single circuit can reduce ancillary modes versus two isolated swap setups.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only demands:  \n  \u2022 single-photon emitters (modeling the Rydberg sites)  \n  \u2022 linear-optical mixing and post-selected photon counting  \n  \u2022 no feedback loops or cavities  \n  \u2022 a clear quantum-network task (two-hop entanglement swapping) rather than standalone state generation  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement).     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d and \u201centangled quantum state\u201d as a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no direct state generation):\n  1) A linear repeater chain of four Rydberg nodes (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D) performing two back\u2010to\u2010back entanglement\u2010swap measurements in one static interferometer to link A and D.\n  2) A hub\u2010and\u2010spoke distribution: several Rydberg emitters send photons to a central station to distribute entanglement to many leaves (a star network), with post\u2010selected joint measurements.\n  3) A coherent \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two entanglement\u2010swap channels: entangle A and D by superposing the two possible mediator nodes B or C in indistinguishable paths, erasing which\u2010mediator information via a small interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty and feasibility check:\n  1) Pure chain of swaps is already closely related to known multi\u2010swap experiments.\n  2) Hub\u2010and\u2010spoke tends toward GHZ/state\u2010generation, which is disallowed.\n  3) The coherent\u2010swap\u2010superposition isn\u2019t in the existing list, goes beyond mere chain lengthening, uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection, and directly addresses a novel network transformation (indefinite\u2010mediator entanglement swapping).\n\nStep 3: Choose idea #3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design implements entanglement swapping through a coherent superposition of two distinct mediator nodes. It realizes a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swap channels in a single static optical circuit.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single\u2010photon emitters (modeling Rydberg sites), linear\u2010optical mixing (to erase which\u2010mediator information), and photon\u2010number detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no direct state generation, just a clear post\u2010selected network task.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two-Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C, D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the circuit. We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. Both the foundational entanglement\u2010swapping experiment (Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted) and its multi\u2010swap extensions (e.g. Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs, the \u201cbutterfly\u201d four\u2010photon joint measurement, or the one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeater) already cover this construction. As a trivial chain\u2010lengthening of known schemes, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two-Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C, D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the circuit. We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal is effectively the same primitive as an entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch or indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping\u2014heralding A\u2013D Bell correlations via a coherent superposition of mediation through B or C. Nearly identical targets appear in both the ensemble\u2019s \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch\u201d (superposing two swap sequences) and the cyclic indefinite\u2010order swap proposals. There\u2019s no new resource or mechanism beyond known optical quantum\u2010switch experiments, so it lacks the novelty needed for a PRL\u2010worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially the same as the entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch and other indefinite\u2010order swapping schemes already in the literature. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d and \u201centangled quantum state\u201d as a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no direct state generation):\n  1) A linear repeater chain of four Rydberg nodes (A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D) performing two back\u2010to\u2010back entanglement\u2010swap measurements in one static interferometer to link A and D.\n  2) A hub\u2010and\u2010spoke distribution: several Rydberg emitters send photons to a central station to distribute entanglement to many leaves (a star network), with post\u2010selected joint measurements.\n  3) A coherent \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two entanglement\u2010swap channels: entangle A and D by superposing the two possible mediator nodes B or C in indistinguishable paths, erasing which\u2010mediator information via a small interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty and feasibility check:\n  1) Pure chain of swaps is already closely related to known multi\u2010swap experiments.\n  2) Hub\u2010and\u2010spoke tends toward GHZ/state\u2010generation, which is disallowed.\n  3) The coherent\u2010swap\u2010superposition isn\u2019t in the existing list, goes beyond mere chain lengthening, uses only static linear optics and post\u2010selection, and directly addresses a novel network transformation (indefinite\u2010mediator entanglement swapping).\n\nStep 3: Choose idea #3.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design implements entanglement swapping through a coherent superposition of two distinct mediator nodes. It realizes a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swap channels in a single static optical circuit.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single\u2010photon emitters (modeling Rydberg sites), linear\u2010optical mixing (to erase which\u2010mediator information), and photon\u2010number detection\u2014no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no direct state generation, just a clear post\u2010selected network task.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two-Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C, D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the circuit. We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially the same as the entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch and other indefinite\u2010order swapping schemes already in the literature.     "output": "Here is a Pytheus\u2010compatible proposal that marries a Rydberg\u2010atom\u2010array memory network to a novel \u201cquantum\u2010switch\u201d style entanglement\u2010swapping:\n\nDescription:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two\u2010Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A, B, C, D.  In Pytheus each Rydberg site is emulated by a two\u2010mode probabilistic pair source which emits one photon toward the end\u2010node (A or D) and one photon toward the intermediate node (B or C).  We prepare two independent entangled pairs (A\u2194B and C\u2194D) along one \u201cchannel\u201d and two more (A\u2194C and B\u2194D) along the other channel.  Then we erase the which\u2010channel information by interfering the four intermediate photons in a small static linear\u2010optical subnetwork.  Post\u2010selecting on four ancilla clicks projects the remaining two modes at A and D into a Bell state\u2014realizing entanglement via a coherent superposition of two distinct swap\u2010channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n emitters (pair sources):  \n   \u2022 Pair1 emits to modes [0:A_out] & [2:B\u2081]  \n   \u2022 Pair2 emits to modes [1:D_out] & [3:B\u2082]  \n   \u2022 Pair3 emits to modes [0:A_out] & [4:C\u2081]  \n   \u2022 Pair4 emits to modes [1:D_out] & [5:C\u2082]  \n static linear\u2010optical network: mixes ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} via beam splitters to erase \u201cB vs. C\u201d path info  \n detectors:  \n   \u2022 0 \u2192 A_out (final qubit)  \n   \u2022 1 \u2192 D_out (final qubit)  \n   \u2022 2,3,4,5 \u2192 ancillary detectors (heralding the switch\u2010swap)  \n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,1],[0,3],[0,5],[1,2],[1,4]]  \n   (forbid any unwanted pair source linking A\u2194D directly or cross\u2010linking ancilla to the wrong output)  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]  \n\nBecause the four ancilla photons are interfered before detection, a click pattern in {2,3,4,5} heralds that A and D have been entangled by a *superposition* of the B\u2013swap and C\u2013swap channels.  This circuit requires no feed\u2010forward, uses only static linear optics and pair sources (emulating Rydberg emitters), and implements a new network primitive\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of entanglement\u2010swap pathways\u2014that directly generalizes to larger superposed\u2010topology repeater modules.\n\nFull Pytheus config (schematic):\n\n{\n  description: \"Coherent two-channel entanglement swapping (quantum switch) between nodes A and D via mediators B and C (Rydberg array emulated by pair sources).\",\n  foldername: \"switch_ES_rydberg\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[0,5],[1,2],[1,4]],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  novac: null,\n  loops: null,\n  topopt: null,\n  dimensions: [],\n  brutal_covers: null,\n  verts: [],\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]\n}"

    "output": "Here is a single, self\u2010contained Pytheus target that combines \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (as single\u2010photon emitters) with a nontrivial quantum\u2010network transformation (purification + swap) without ever \u201cgenerating\u201d a new multi\u2010partite state:\n\nDescription:  \n\u201cSimultaneous Entanglement-Purification\u2009+\u2009Entanglement-Swapping Repeater Module for a Rydberg-Atom Array\u201d\n\nExplanation:  \nWe label three remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C. Each node is realized as a single\u2010photon emitter in the linear-optical network:  \n \u2022 Emitter 0 \u2194 node A  \n \u2022 Emitters 1 & 2 \u2194 node B (two noisy links AB and BC)  \n \u2022 Emitter 3 \u2194 node C  \n\nGoal: start from two imperfect Bell pairs\u2014one between A\u2013B (via emitters 0&1) and one between B\u2013C (via emitters 2&3)\u2014and in one static circuit perform:  \n  1) a parity\u2010check purification on B\u2019s two photons (emitters 1&2), and  \n  2) a Bell\u2010measurement\u2010style entanglement swap between the purified AB photon and the BC photon,  \nall by post-selecting on clicks in four ancilla detectors. Successful heralding projects the remaining modes at A and C into a high-fidelity two-qubit Bell state \u222300\u3009+\u222311\u3009.  \n\nVisualization (from top to bottom):  \n Emitters:   [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C]  \n  \u2193            \u2193        \u2193        \u2193  \n  \u201cPurification beam-splitter\u201d mixing outputs 1&2 \u2192 Ancilla detectors [2],[3]  \n  \u201cSwap beam-splitter\u201d mixing one purified photon from B with the C photon \u2192 Ancilla detectors [4],[5]  \n Detectors:  [0:A_out] [1:C_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]  \n\nConstraints:  \n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2,3]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4   (ancilla detectors 2\u20135)  \n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,1],[0,2],[0,3],  [1,0],[1,1],[1,2]]  \n   \u2013 forbids any unwanted direct link from B\u2010 or C\u2010emitters into A_out (detector 0) and from A\u2010 or B\u2010emitters into C_out (detector 1)  \n \u2022 number_resolving = True  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11']   (on detectors [0,1])  \n \u2022 thresholds = [0.3, 0.1]  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:  \n Pytheus\u2019s library so far includes plain entanglement swapping or multi-dimensional Bell-state creation, but never a repeater module that fuses purification + swap in one passive circuit. We aren\u2019t \u201cstate-generating\u201d a GHZ or cluster state\u2014we\u2019re enacting a nontrivial two-step network transformation that (i) filters noise and (ii) extends entanglement, all in one go.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s Pytheus-feasible:  \n \u2022 All resources are single-photon emitters + linear optics + post-selected photon counting (no cavities or feedback).  \n \u2022 The physical \u201crydberg array\u201d sits underneath as the emitter technology but Pytheus only needs abstract emitters.  \n \u2022 The task is pure quantum networking\u2014perfectly suited to Pytheus\u2019s abstract-state formalism and topology optimization."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': A three-branch \u201centanglement\u2010switch\u201d provides a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014indefinite\u2010mediator swapping with higher\u2010order superposition.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2022 Uses 8 single-photon emitters (A, B\u2081, B\u2082, C\u2081, C\u2082, D\u2081, D\u2082, E)  \n    \u2022 Static linear optics to mix mediator photons, erasing which\u2010branch info  \n    \u2022 Photon-number detection (no feedback loops)  \n    \u2022 Post-selection on ancilla detectors heralds a Bell state between A and E  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cThree-Branch Coherent Entanglement Swap via Rydberg-Array Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg sites by eight single-photon emitters:\n  Emitters: [0:A], [1:B\u2081], [2:B\u2082], [3:C\u2081], [4:C\u2082], [5:D\u2081], [6:D\u2082], [7:E].\n\nGoal:\nPost-selectively project the two output modes at detectors 0 and 7 into the Bell state |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories  \n\nMini-Abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded telecloning channel that maps an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 at node A onto two approximate clones at nodes B and C by routing its excitation into two lossy memory modes and then swapping them back via tunable beam splitters. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. As a trivial chain\u2010lengthening of known schemes, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is effectively the same primitive as an entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch or indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping\u2014heralding A\u2013D Bell correlations via a coherent superposition of mediation through B or C. two\u2010path superposition of standard swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cThree-Branch Coherent Entanglement Swap via Rydberg-Array Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg sites by eight single-photon emitters:\n  Emitters: [0:A], [1:B\u2081], [2:B\u2082], [3:C\u2081], [4:C\u2082], [5:D\u2081], [6:D\u2082], [7:E].\n\nGoal:\nPost-selectively project the two output modes at detectors 0 and 7 into the Bell state |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too     "output": "Thought: While extending entanglement swapping to three parallel mediator branches may sound like a longer chain, it is essentially the same primitive as the \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four\u2010Node Photonic Circuit,\u201d both of which already realize coherent superpositions of multiple swap channels in one shot. Simply going from two to three branches\u2014even with Rydberg-array emitters\u2014does not introduce a qualitatively new resource or protocol, but is a trivial generalization of known multi\u2010path swap schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. To be PRL-worthy, you must introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. non-trivial causal order beyond multi-branch superposition, integration of a novel non-linear interaction, or a topologically protected mediation mechanism\u2014not merely increase the number of swapping arms."
