    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Eavesdropper localization for quantum and classical channels via\n  nonlinear scattering\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Quantum and semi--quantum key distribution in networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': A three-branch \u201centanglement\u2010switch\u201d provides a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014indefinite\u2010mediator swapping with higher\u2010order superposition.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2022 Uses 8 single-photon emitters (A, B\u2081, B\u2082, C\u2081, C\u2082, D\u2081, D\u2082, E)  \n    \u2022 Static linear optics to mix mediator photons, erasing which\u2010branch info  \n    \u2022 Photon-number detection (no feedback loops)  \n    \u2022 Post-selection on ancilla detectors heralds a Bell state between A and E  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cThree-Branch Coherent Entanglement Swap via Rydberg-Array Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg sites by eight single-photon emitters:\n  Emitters: [0:A], [1:B\u2081], [2:B\u2082], [3:C\u2081], [4:C\u2082], [5:D\u2081], [6:D\u2082], [7:E].\n\nGoal:\nPost-selectively project the two output modes at detectors 0 and 7 into the Bell state |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. To be PRL-worthy, you must introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. non-trivial causal order beyond multi-branch superposition, integration of a novel non-linear interaction, or a topologically protected mediation mechanism\u2014not merely increase the number of swapping arms.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2013compatible ways to fuse \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (modeled by single-photon emitters) with a nontrivial entangled-network transformation rather than mere state generation:\n  1) A four-node chain of two sequential swaps (A\u2013B then C\u2013D) to link end nodes A and D\u2014too close to existing multi-swap examples.\n  2) A star/hub entanglement distributor (many emitters to one central joint measurement)\u2014edges toward GHZ/state gen, disallowed.\n  3) A single static \u201centanglement\u2010router\u201d that can post-selectively entangle any chosen pair of four Rydberg nodes (A,B,C,D) by heralding on different patterns of ancilla detectors.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n  1) Chain of swaps is already covered by extended entanglement-swapping examples.\n  2) Star hub is effectively GHZ generation, which is forbidden.\n  3) The reconfigurable router is not in the existing list. It only requires single-photon emitters, linear optics, and post-selection; no feedback or cavities\u2014fully Pytheus-compatible.\n\nStep 3: Select idea #3.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  No previous Pytheus design implements a single static interferometer that, by conditioning on different ancilla detection patterns, can route entanglement to different client pairs on demand. This realizes a truly reconfigurable quantum\u2010network primitive in one device.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses N=4 Rydberg sites \u2192 4 single-photon emitters  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical mixing + 6 detectors (2 outputs, 4 ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections forbid direct emitter\u2192output shortcuts  \n  \u2022 Target quantum for each heralding pattern is a Bell state on the chosen pair  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement references  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cReconfigurable Entanglement Router for Four Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites by four independent single-photon emitters A, B, C, D. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus."
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. Both the foundational entanglement\u2010swapping experiment (Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted) and its multi\u2010swap extensions (e.g. Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs, the \u201cbutterfly\u201d four\u2010photon joint measurement, or the one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeater) already cover this construction. As a trivial chain\u2010lengthening of known schemes, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two-Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C, D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the circuit. We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is effectively the same primitive as an entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch or indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping\u2014heralding A\u2013D Bell correlations via a coherent superposition of mediation through B or C. Nearly identical targets appear in both the ensemble\u2019s \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch\u201d (superposing two swap sequences) and the cyclic indefinite\u2010order swap proposals. There\u2019s no new resource or mechanism beyond known optical quantum\u2010switch experiments, so it lacks the novelty needed for a PRL\u2010worthy target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is essentially the same as the entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch and other indefinite\u2010order swapping schemes already in the literature. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new twist\u2014e.g. a different physical resource, higher\u2010order causal structures, or topologically nontrivial superpositions\u2014not just two\u2010path superposition of standard swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cThree-Branch Coherent Entanglement Swap via Rydberg-Array Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg sites by eight single-photon emitters:\n  Emitters: [0:A], [1:B\u2081], [2:B\u2082], [3:C\u2081], [4:C\u2082], [5:D\u2081], [6:D\u2082], [7:E].\n\nGoal:\nPost-selectively project the two output modes at detectors 0 and 7 into the Bell state |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While extending entanglement swapping to three parallel mediator branches may sound like a longer chain, it is essentially the same primitive as the \u201centanglement\u2010switch quantum switch\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four\u2010Node Photonic Circuit,\u201d both of which already realize coherent superpositions of multiple swap channels in one shot. Simply going from two to three branches\u2014even with Rydberg-array emitters\u2014does not introduce a qualitatively new resource or protocol, but is a trivial generalization of known multi\u2010path swap schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. To be PRL-worthy, you must introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. non-trivial causal order beyond multi-branch superposition, integration of a novel non-linear interaction, or a topologically protected mediation mechanism\u2014not merely increase the number of swapping arms.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cReconfigurable Entanglement Router for Four Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites by four independent single-photon emitters A, B, C, D. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While offering a useful modular repeater\u2010style component, this \u201creconfigurable entanglement router\u201d is essentially the same static, heralding\u2010pattern\u2013driven entanglement\u2010switch or router already proposed\u2014e.g. the Pythreus\u2010compatible \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d\u2014merely extended to four nodes. It lacks a qualitatively new mechanism or resource beyond selecting different ancilla\u2010click patterns to choose between links.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. Combining both swaps in a single circuit can reduce ancillary modes versus two isolated swap setups.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only demands:  \n  \u2022 single-photon emitters (modeling the Rydberg sites)  \n  \u2022 linear-optical mixing and post-selected photon counting  \n  \u2022 no feedback loops or cavities  \n  \u2022 a clear quantum-network task (two-hop entanglement swapping) rather than standalone state generation  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled by single\u2010photon emitters) with a nontrivial quantum\u2010network transformation (no pure state generation):\n  1) A chain of two sequential entanglement swaps between A\u2013B and C\u2013D to link A and D (too close to existing multi\u2010swap examples).\n  2) A star/hub distribution to many leaves (tends toward GHZ generation, disallowed).\n  3) A single integrated circuit that simultaneously purifies three weak Bell pairs (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D) and swaps at B and C in one step, projecting A\u2013D into a high-fidelity Bell state\u2014i.e. one\u2010shot entanglement\u2010distillation + swapping.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & feasibility check:\n  \u2022 #1 is just lengthening known entanglement-swap chains.\n  \u2022 #2 drifts into multi-party state generation.\n  \u2022 #3 has no analogue in the explored list, uses only linear optics and post-selection, no feedback or cavities, purely a quantum-network primitive.\n\nStep 3: Pick #3.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  No existing Pytheus design bundles entanglement distillation and swapping into a single static interferometer. This \u201cone-shot distil-and-swap\u201d circuit can outperform two separate steps by reducing resource overhead and losses.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses three probabilistic photon-pair sources (modeling Rydberg sites creating weak Bell pairs)  \n  \u2022 An 8-mode linear-optical network mixing the four \u201cmiddle\u201d photons for joint purification+swap  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors only, no dynamic control  \n  \u2022 Output: detectors 0 and 1 carry a purified Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 upon heralding clicks in the four ancilla detectors  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSimultaneous Entanglement Distillation and Swapping in One Static Circuit\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four Rydberg-array nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by three probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to B-input (mode 2).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits one photon to B\u2032-input (mode 3) and one to C-input (mode 4).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2083 emits one photon to C\u2032-input (mode 5) and one to node D (detector 1).\n\nThese three sources each produce imperfect Bell pairs. A static linear-optical mesh mixes the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (2,3,4,5) so that a specific four-click pattern in ancilla detectors heralds both:\n  1) Distillation of the two weak Bell pairs B\u2013C  \n  2) Entanglement swapping that projects A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Emitters (sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083) \u2192 linear-optical network mixing modes [2,3,4,5] \u2192 Detectors:\n    \u2022 Output nodes (post-selected pair): [0:A_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 Ancilla detectors: [2,3,4,5] (herald purification+swap)\n\nKey Pytheus config hints:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:\n      \u2013 forbid any source from connecting directly to both outputs: [[0,1]]  \n      \u2013 enforce S\u2081\u2192(0,2), S\u2082\u2192(3,4), S\u2083\u2192(5,1] and remove all other cross-links  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n  \u2022 no single_emitters, no loops, number_resolving = True  \n  \u2022 loss_func = 'cr', optimizer = 'L-BFGS-B\u2019, etc.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N weak links in series, designing one\u2010shot circuits that perform multi-pair distillation + swap in one go.  \n  \u2013 Apply to Rydberg arrays by mapping each weak Bell pair to two-photon excitations from adjacent atoms, with emitted photons fed into the Pytheus\u2010designed interferometer.  \n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrated distillation + swapping\u2014opens a new class of repeater primitives beyond simple sequential swapping."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs     "output": "Thought: This \u201csimultaneous distillation\u2009+\u2009swap\u201d circuit is essentially the same one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeater already in the ensemble (\u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\u201d). Both use a static interferometer to perform entanglement purification or concentration on two weak links and immediately swap to produce a heralded high-fidelity Bell pair. Simply adding a third source or renaming nodes doesn\u2019t introduce a fundamentally new mechanism.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Your scheme duplicates the one-shot swap-and-concentrate primitive from the ensemble. To be novel, you need a new resource or operational principle beyond combining distillation and swapping in a single post-selected linear-optical network."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Eavesdropper localization for quantum and classical channels via\n  nonlinear scattering\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Quantum and semi--quantum key distribution in networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is essentially the same as the entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch and other indefinite\u2010order swapping schemes already in the literature. [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing
