    "output": "Here is a concrete Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network \u201cmeasurement\u201d primitive that (a) directly combines a Rydberg\u2010array (modeled as single\u2010photon emitters) and an entangled quantum state, (b) is not just state generation but implements a fundamental network transformation, and (c) can be generalized to larger analyzers (GHZ, cluster\u2010state bases, etc.):  \n\nDescription:  \n\u201cComplete Ancilla-Assisted Bell\u2010State Analyzer via Rydberg-Array Photons\u201d  \n\nGoal:  \nGiven two unknown qubits (modes A and B) that may be in one of the four Bell states, implement a static linear-optical circuit (no feedback) with four ancilla photons (each from a Rydberg-atom emitter) and number-resolving detectors, such that each of the four Bell basis inputs is routed to a distinct click pattern.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and new:  \n1) A deterministic (100%-success) linear-optical Bell\u2010measurement requires ancillary photons and number-resolving detectors. To our knowledge no Pytheus example yet tackles the qubit-Bell\u2010analyzer (only 3D analyzers exist).  \n2) This device is a core building block for teleportation and repeater networks\u2014an essential \u201cswap+readout\u201d node.  \n3) It generalizes immediately: one can ask Pytheus for analyzers of 3-, 4-, N-qubit entangled bases (GHZ, cluster, etc.) by increasing ancilla and detector modes.  \n\nHigh-level configuration:  \n\u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2,3,4,5]  \n   \u2013 emitters 0&1 = signal qubits \u201cA\u201d and \u201cB\u201d (the two\u2010photon Bell input)  \n   \u2013 emitters 2,3,4,5 = ancilla photons from four Rydberg array sites  \n\u2022 num_anc = 6   (total detectors excluding 0&1)  \n\u2022 out_nodes = []   (we read off the result purely from which ancilla detectors click)  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [0\u20265]  (all six detectors produce the measurement outcome)  \n\u2022 removed_connections:  \n    \u2013 forbid any single emitter from sending two photons to the same detector  \n    \u2013 forbid direct routing that would let two signal photons click the same output without interference  \n  (Pytheus will enforce these automatically once you tell it which emitters feed which detectors are disallowed.)  \n\u2022 target_quantum = four orthonormal six-photon detection\u2010pattern states, each corresponding to one Bell basis input:  \n   e.g.  \n     \u2013 Input |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2192 clicks on detectors [2,4]  \n     \u2013 Input |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2192 clicks on [2,5]  \n     \u2013 Input |\u03a8\u207a\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2192 clicks on [3,4]  \n     \u2013 Input |\u03a8\u207b\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2192 clicks on [3,5]  \n   (exact patterns must be optimized by Pytheus under \u201ctarget_quantum\u201d as 6-mode Fock strings.)  \n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \n Emitters: [0:A] [1:B] [2:anc] [3:anc] [4:anc] [5:anc]  \n      \u2193       \u2193       \u2193 [d\u2080] [d\u2081] [d\u2082] [d\u2083] [d\u2084] [d\u2085]  \n\nInterpretation:  \n  \u2013 We feed the two Bell-qubit photons into modes 0 and 1.  \n  \u2013 Four ancilla photons from Rydberg emitters supply the nonlinearity resource.  \n  \u2013 Pytheus will find the beamsplitter + phase-shifter arrangement that maps each of the four Bell states onto one unique six-click pattern among d\u2082\u2026d\u2085.  \n\nGeneralization:  \n  \u2022 Extend to a GHZ-basis analyzer for three qubits by adding three more ancillas and detectors; specify an 8-photon target for the 8 GHZ basis measurement\u2014rather than state generation.  \n"

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Eavesdropper localization for quantum and classical channels via\n  nonlinear scattering\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Quantum and semi--quantum key distribution in networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. To be PRL-worthy, you must introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. non-trivial causal order beyond multi-branch superposition, integration of a novel non-linear interaction, or a topologically protected mediation mechanism\u2014not merely increase the number of swapping arms.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! This realizes a truly reconfigurable quantum\u2010network primitive in one device.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses N=4 Rydberg sites \u2192 4 single-photon emitters  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical mixing + 6 detectors (2 outputs, 4 ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections forbid direct emitter\u2192output shortcuts  \n  \u2022 Target quantum for each heralding pattern is a Bell state on the chosen pair  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement references  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cReconfigurable Entanglement Router for Four Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites by four independent single-photon emitters A, B, C, D. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. A static linear-optical mesh mixes the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (2,3,4,5) so that a specific four-click pattern in ancilla detectors heralds both:\n  1) Distillation of the two weak Bell pairs B\u2013C  \n  2) Entanglement swapping that projects A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Emitters (sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083) \u2192 linear-optical network mixing modes [2,3,4,5] \u2192 Detectors:\n    \u2022 Output nodes (post-selected pair): [0:A_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 Ancilla detectors: [2,3,4,5] (herald purification+swap)\n\nKey Pytheus config hints:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:\n      \u2013 forbid any source from connecting directly to both outputs: [[0,1]]  \n      \u2013 enforce S\u2081\u2192(0,2), S\u2082\u2192(3,4), S\u2083\u2192(5,1] and remove all other cross-links  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n  \u2022 no single_emitters, no loops, number_resolving = True  \n  \u2022 loss_func = 'cr', optimizer = 'L-BFGS-B\u2019, etc.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N weak links in series, designing one\u2010shot circuits that perform multi-pair distillation + swap in one go.  \n  \u2013 Apply to Rydberg arrays by mapping each weak Bell pair to two-photon excitations from adjacent atoms, with emitted photons fed into the Pytheus\u2010designed interferometer.  \n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrated distillation + swapping\u2014opens a new class of repeater primitives beyond simple sequential swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the one-shot swap-and-concentrate primitive from the ensemble.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled as independent single-photon emitters in Pytheus) with a genuinely new quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A static linear-optical network that implements a near-complete Bell-state analyzer for two photonic qubits by injecting two ancilla photons (from Rydberg emitters) and post-selecting on distinctive click patterns.  \n  2) A single circuit that simultaneously teleports two logical qubits across four Rydberg nodes in one \u201cdouble-teleportation\u201d step\u2014cross-swap of two qubits in parallel.  \n  3) A reconfigurable \u201centanglement router\u201d that, conditional on which subset of ancilla detectors clicks, entangles one of three possible remote node-pairs among four Rydberg sites in a single static interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus-feasibility:\n  1) The Bell-state analyzer is a measurement-network primitive (a transformation), not just creating a Bell pair. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While offering a useful modular repeater\u2010style component, this \u201creconfigurable entanglement router\u201d is essentially the same static, heralding\u2010pattern\u2013driven entanglement\u2010switch or router already proposed\u2014e.g. the Pythreus\u2010compatible \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d\u2014merely extended to four nodes. Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons.     "output": "Thought: This proposal boils down to yet another near\u2010complete Bell measurement using two ancilla photons in a static linear\u2010optical network\u2014a primitive already explored in numerous works (e.g. Grice\u2019s near\u2010deterministic Bell analyzer with ancillas) and paralleled by ensemble entries like the \u201cSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer\u201d and various ancilla-assisted GHZ and high-dimensional Bell analyzers. There is no genuinely new resource or measurement principle here\u2014merely renaming the extra photons as \u201cRydberg-sourced ancillas.\u201d This lacks the conceptual novelty required for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics."

Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer).     "output": "Here\u2019s a target that (a) uses Rydberg-array sites as on-demand single-photon emitters, (b) implements a genuine quantum-network task (teleportation) in a fully static, post-selected linear-optics circuit, and (c) generalizes immediately to N-channel teleportation:\n\nDescription:  \n\u201cDual-Channel Post-Selective Teleportation via Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nGoal:  \nPost-selectively teleport two unknown qubit states, prepared at two \u201cclient\u201d Rydberg sites Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, to two \u201creceiver\u201d output modes, using two Bell-pair ancillas supplied by four additional Rydberg emitters. All four photons (two inputs + two ancillas per channel) feed into one fixed interferometer; by conditioning on the two Bell-measurement outcomes both being the \u201cno-correction\u201d result, the qubits emerge at the two designated output detectors.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters (single_emitters):  \n    [0: Q\u2081_in]   \u2013 the first unknown qubit  \n    [1: A\u2081]      \u2013 ancilla half-pair for channel 1  \n    [2: A\u2082]      \u2013 ancilla half-pair for channel 1  \n    [3: Q\u2082_in]   \u2013 the second unknown qubit  \n    [4: B\u2081]      \u2013 ancilla half-pair for channel 2  \n    [5: B\u2082]      \u2013 ancilla half-pair for channel 2  \n\n  Static LO network: mixes all six modes so that performing two Bell-measurements in parallel is possible.  \n\n  Detectors:  \n    \u2022 [D0, D1] \u2192 output modes  (teleported Q\u2081, Q\u2082)  \n    \u2022 [D2, D3] \u2192 Bell-measurement for Q\u2081 + {A\u2081,A\u2082}  \n    \u2022 [D4, D5] \u2192 Bell-measurement for Q\u2082 + {B\u2081,B\u2082}  \n\nConfiguration hints for Pytheus:  \n  description      = \"Dual-Channel Post-Selective Teleportation\"  \n  foldername       = \"dual_teleport\"  \n  single_emitters  = [0,1,2,3,4,5]  \n  num_anc          = 4        // ancilla detectors: D2\u2013D5  \n  out_nodes        = [0,1]    // D0,D1 carry teleported qubits  \n  anc_detectors    = [2,3,4,5]  \n  removed_connections = [  \n     // forbid any direct emitter\u2192output shortcut  \n     [0,0],[1,0],[2,0],   // none of Q\u2081,A\u2081,A\u2082 \u2192 D0 except via LO  \n     [3,1],[4,1],[5,1]    // none of Q\u2082,B\u2081,B\u2082 \u2192 D1 except via LO  \n  ]  \n  target_quantum   = [\"00\",\"11\"]  // at [D0,D1], conditional on both Bell-measurements yielding the \"+1\" outcome  \n\nHow it works:  \n  1) Channels 1 and 2 each share a Bell-pair ancilla (A\u2081\u2013A\u2082, B\u2081\u2013B\u2082).  \n  2) Q\u2081 and its ancilla mix in a sub-block of the interferometer that implements a Bell measurement; similarly for Q\u2082 and its ancilla.  \n  3) We post-select on exactly the \u201cidentity\u201d Bell outcome for each channel (heralded by a specific two-click pattern on D2\u2013D3 and D4\u2013D5).  \n  4) In those cases, the unknown qubit from Q\u2081 emerges undisturbed at D0, and the one from Q\u2082 at D1.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:  \n  \u2022 This is the first Pytheus\u2010style design for *parallel* teleportation of two qubits in one static circuit.  \n  \u2022 You avoid any dynamic feed-forward by post-selecting only the no-correction outcomes.  \n  \u2022 Scaling to N-channel teleportation is immediate: add 2N ancilla emitters, expand the LO to 4N modes, and post-select on N Bell-\u201cno-correction\u201d click patterns.  \n  \u2022 Implements a fundamental network primitive (multi\u2010channel teleportation) rather than state generation.  \n  \u2022 Maps directly onto Rydberg\u2010array technology: each emitter is a Rydberg excitation that emits a photon on demand.\n\nSuch a circuit, once found by Pytheus, would enable a physics\u2010letter on multi-channel teleportation modules for modular Rydberg quantum networks."

Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Eavesdropper localization for quantum and classical channels via\n  nonlinear scattering\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Quantum and semi--quantum key distribution in networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state.
