Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It\u2019s a measurement\u2010network (a three-photon, static interferometer) that performs a non-demolition Z\u2297Z parity check on two data qubits by injecting a single ancilla photon.  All resources\u2014single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s remit; no cavities or feedback.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  Pytheus has not produced a linear-optical network for a heralded parity measurement on two qubits with minimal ancilla.  This provides a new entanglement-purification/ error-detection primitive for quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2]  (qubit A, qubit B, ancilla)  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 0  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0\u20263] for \u201ceven\u201d outcomes, [4\u20267] for \u201codd\u201d  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = map the 2\u00d72\u00d72=8 basis states |x y z\u27e9 to eight distinct output modes, grouped by parity of x\u2295y  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = forbid direct emitter\u2192wrong-parity detectors  \n  \u2022 purely static beam splitters & phase shifts + number-resolving detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Parity Analyzer for Two Qubits Using a Rydberg Ancilla Photon\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote qubit-photons (from two Rydberg atoms) as single-photon emitters Q\u2081 (emitter 0) and Q\u2082 (emitter 1), plus one ancilla photon from a third Rydberg site (emitter 2). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal boils down to yet another near\u2010complete Bell measurement using two ancilla photons in a static linear\u2010optical network\u2014a primitive already explored in numerous works (e.g. Grice\u2019s near\u2010deterministic Bell analyzer with ancillas) and paralleled by ensemble entries like the \u201cSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer\u201d and various ancilla-assisted GHZ and high-dimensional Bell analyzers. There is no genuinely new resource or measurement principle here\u2014merely renaming the extra photons as \u201cRydberg-sourced ancillas.\u201d This lacks the conceptual novelty required for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Parity Analyzer for Two Qubits Using a Rydberg Ancilla Photon\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote qubit-photons (from two Rydberg atoms) as single-photon emitters Q\u2081 (emitter 0) and Q\u2082 (emitter 1), plus one ancilla photon from a third Rydberg site (emitter 2). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This is just a two-qubit Z\u2297Z parity measurement implemented by routing three photons through a static interferometer\u2014essentially a miniaturized Bell\u2010measurement or parity\u2010check circuit with one ancilla. Very similar parity gates and one-shot stabilizer readouts already appear (e.g. the semi-quantum key-agreement nonlocal XOR primitive and the toric-code parity readout) and Bell analyzers routinely extract parity. There\u2019s no new resource or mechanism beyond renaming an extra photon \u201cRydberg ancilla.\u201d  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). To be PRL-worthy, you need a truly novel twist\u2014e.g. exploiting genuine Rydberg interactions in-circuit, achieving deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a new degree of freedom\u2014rather than a trivial parity\u2010check mapping."

collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled as independent single-photon emitters in Pytheus) with a genuinely new quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A static linear-optical network that implements a near-complete Bell-state analyzer for two photonic qubits by injecting two ancilla photons (from Rydberg emitters) and post-selecting on distinctive click patterns.  \n  2) A single circuit that simultaneously teleports two logical qubits across four Rydberg nodes in one \u201cdouble-teleportation\u201d step\u2014cross-swap of two qubits in parallel.  \n  3) A reconfigurable \u201centanglement router\u201d that, conditional on which subset of ancilla detectors clicks, entangles one of three possible remote node-pairs among four Rydberg sites in a single static interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus-feasibility:\n  1) The Bell-state analyzer is a measurement-network primitive (a transformation), not just creating a Bell pair. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to fuse \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (as single\u2010photon emitters) with a genuinely new quantum-network transformation (no pure state generation):\n  1) A two-step distil-and-swap circuit (we already tried; too close to known designs).\n  2) A reconfigurable entanglement router (close to prior \u201cmultiplexed swap\u201d ideas).\n  3) A heralded parity-check analyzer on two photonic qubits using one Rydberg-sourced ancilla photon.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 Idea (3) has no analogue in Pytheus\u2019s list.  It\u2019s a measurement\u2010network (a three-photon, static interferometer) that performs a non-demolition Z\u2297Z parity check on two data qubits by injecting a single ancilla photon.  All resources\u2014single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s remit; no cavities or feedback.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  Pytheus has not produced a linear-optical network for a heralded parity measurement on two qubits with minimal ancilla.  This provides a new entanglement-purification/ error-detection primitive for quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2]  (qubit A, qubit B, ancilla)  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 0  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0\u20263] for \u201ceven\u201d outcomes, [4\u20267] for \u201codd\u201d  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = map the 2\u00d72\u00d72=8 basis states |x y z\u27e9 to eight distinct output modes, grouped by parity of x\u2295y  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = forbid direct emitter\u2192wrong-parity detectors  \n  \u2022 purely static beam splitters & phase shifts + number-resolving detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Parity Analyzer for Two Qubits Using a Rydberg Ancilla Photon\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote qubit-photons (from two Rydberg atoms) as single-photon emitters Q\u2081 (emitter 0) and Q\u2082 (emitter 1), plus one ancilla photon from a third Rydberg site (emitter 2). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). To be PRL-worthy, you need a truly novel twist\u2014e.g. exploiting genuine Rydberg interactions in-circuit, achieving deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a new degree of freedom\u2014rather than a trivial parity\u2010check mapping.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (modeled by single-photon emitters) with a nontrivial quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A tunable partial-Bell measurement on the two middle photons of a two-hop chain, using two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons, to realize \u201cpartial entanglement swapping\u201d with continuously adjustable fidelity vs. success probability.  \n  2) A single static interferometer that, by different ancilla-click patterns, implements either a Bell swap between A\u2013D or a direct teleportation from A\u2192D, demonstrating a \u201cdual-mode repeater\u201d in one device.  \n  3) A three-photon coherent control measurement: measure the joint parity of three photons via one Rydberg ancilla, enabling a \u201cthree-party entanglement router\u201d\u2014but this drifts toward state generation.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus-feasibility:\n  \u2022 Idea 1 (partial-swap) is not on the existing list. It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal merely implements a tunable-weight entanglement swap\u2014a partial\u2010swap that yields cos\u03b8|00\u27e9+sin\u03b8|11\u27e9\u2014using reflectivity and phase as controls. A nearly identical mechanism appears in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cPT\u2010Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non\u2010Hermitian Bell\u2010State Projection,\u201d which produces |HH\u27e9+\u03b3 e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable entanglement, and in existing partial-SWAP gates. There is no new resource or fundamentally different protocol here, only a rephrasing of known tunable swap primitives.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs). To be novel, you need a genuinely new mechanism or resource beyond simply varying \u03b8 in a standard swap circuit."

Combining both swaps in a single circuit can reduce ancillary modes versus two isolated swap setups.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only demands:  \n  \u2022 single-photon emitters (modeling the Rydberg sites)  \n  \u2022 linear-optical mixing and post-selected photon counting  \n  \u2022 no feedback loops or cavities  \n  \u2022 a clear quantum-network task (two-hop entanglement swapping) rather than standalone state generation  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (modeled by single-photon emitters) with a nontrivial quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A tunable partial-Bell measurement on the two middle photons of a two-hop chain, using two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons, to realize \u201cpartial entanglement swapping\u201d with continuously adjustable fidelity vs. success probability.  \n  2) A single static interferometer that, by different ancilla-click patterns, implements either a Bell swap between A\u2013D or a direct teleportation from A\u2192D, demonstrating a \u201cdual-mode repeater\u201d in one device.  \n  3) A three-photon coherent control measurement: measure the joint parity of three photons via one Rydberg ancilla, enabling a \u201cthree-party entanglement router\u201d\u2014but this drifts toward state generation.\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus-feasibility:\n  \u2022 Idea 1 (partial-swap) is not on the existing list. It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs).     "output": "Here\u2019s a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network primitive that, to my knowledge, has not been designed before: a heralded photonic Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate.  In addition to being a fundamental three\u2010qubit logic gate, it realizes **entanglement routing**: if T\u2081 and T\u2082 each hold halves of two separate Bell pairs, a successful Fredkin will swap which remote partner is entangled with which\u2014under the coherent control of a Rydberg-array \u201ccontrol\u201d photon.\n\nExplanation of the idea\n  \u2022 We model three logical qubits by single-photon emitters:\n      0 \u2192 Control qubit C  \n      1 \u2192 Target qubit T\u2081  \n      2 \u2192 Target qubit T\u2082  \n  \u2022 We introduce three ancilla photons (from three more Rydberg emitters 3,4,5)  \n  \u2022 All six photons enter a **static** linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters + phases).  \n  \u2022 We post-select on a specific three-click pattern in the ancilla detectors [3,4,5], which **heralds** a successful C-SWAP on qubits 0\u20132.  \n  \u2022 The output modes [0,1,2] then carry the three logical qubits in the transformed basis:\n       |c,t\u2081,t\u2082\u27e9 \u2192 |c, t\u2081\u2295(c\u00b7(t\u2081\u2295t\u2082)), t\u2082\u2295(c\u00b7(t\u2081\u2295t\u2082))\u27e9  \n    (i.e. if c=1 swap t\u2081\u2194t\u2082; if c=0 leave them unchanged.)\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel\n  \u2013 No previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the **Fredkin** gate, only CNOT and Toffoli.  \n  \u2013 This directly implements a **controlled entanglement-swap** (i.e. entanglement router) primitive: downstream one can feed halves of two Bell pairs into T\u2081 and T\u2082, prepare C in a superposition, and post-selectively route entanglement in a coherent superposition to one of two remote nodes\u2014opening a new family of \u201cquantum switch\u201d network protocols.  \n  \u2013 It remains a pure quantum-network transformation (no stand-alone state generation), uses only single-photon emitters, static linear optics, and photon-number detection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nWhy Pytheus can do it\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2,3,4,5]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes     = [0,1,2]   (control-out, target1-out, target2-out)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [3,4,5]   (heralding modes)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:  \n      \u2013 forbid any emitter from sending directly to both a target output and its partner\u2019s output except through the interferometer  \n      \u2013 e.g. remove [[0,1],[0,2],[1,2],[2,1]] so no direct control\u2192target links  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = the 8 computational basis strings mapped through the Fredkin truth table:  \n      ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n      \u2192 corresponding output basis ['000','001','100','101','110','111','010','011']  \n  \u2022 number_resolving = True, loss_func='cr', optimizer='L-BFGS-B', samples=20  \n\nThis heralded Fredkin gate immediately generalizes to larger controlled-routing operations (e.g. multi-branch swap networks) and can serve as a core module for Rydberg-based photonic quantum repeaters, routers, and distributed logic in a true quantum superposition of network topologies."
}

Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles.
