The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs). To be novel, you need a genuinely new mechanism or resource beyond simply varying \u03b8 in a standard swap circuit.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Here is a concrete Pytheus\u2010compatible proposal that fuses a Rydberg\u2010array model (as single\u2010photon/pair emitters) with a genuinely new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014namely **quantum butterfly network coding** via **dual entanglement\u2010swapping**.  \n\nDescription:  \n\u201cQuantum Butterfly Network\u2010Coding via Dual Entanglement Swapping\u201d\n\nExplanation of the idea:  \nWe have four distant Rydberg\u2010array nodes A, B, C, D.  Each node is connected to one of two intermediate \u201cswitch\u201d stations M\u2081 and M\u2082 by a probabilistic Bell\u2010pair photon source:  \n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits to (A, m1\u2081)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits to (B, m1\u2082)  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 emits to (m2\u2081, C)  \n  \u2022 S\u2084 emits to (m2\u2082, D)  \n\nAt the heart of the network is a single static linear\u2010optical circuit that mixes modes  \n  (m1\u2081 \u2194 m2\u2082) and (m1\u2082 \u2194 m2\u2081)  \non beam splitters so as to perform two Bell\u2010measurements **in parallel**\u2014one \u201ccross\u201d swap from A\u2192C and one from B\u2192D.  Post\u2010selecting exactly one photon click in each of the four ancilla detectors at the outputs of that mesh deletes all which\u2010path information and thereby teleports the unknown qubit at A onto C and the unknown qubit at B onto D **simultaneously**, despite the two data streams sharing the same physical bottleneck.  \n\nThis realizes the canonical **butterfly network coding** advantage: two end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation channels share a single switching resource without increasing latency or resource count compared to two independent links.  It is a purely **network** transformation\u2014no new entangled state is simply \u201cproduced,\u201d but rather two unknown qubit\u2010streams are routed crosswise through one static device.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):  \n  Emitters (sources S\u2081\u2026S\u2084)  \n      \u2193  \n  Static beam\u2010splitter mesh (mixes m1\u2081,m2\u2082 and m1\u2082,m2\u2081)  \n      \u2193  \n  Detectors:  \n    \u2022 out_nodes = [0:C_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n\nKey Pytheus\u2010config elements:  \n  description: \"Butterfly network coding with dual entanglement swapping\"  \n  foldername: \"butterfly_code\"  \n  num_pre: 2  \n  num_anc: 4  \n  single_emitters: []               // using 4 probabilistic pair sources instead  \n  removed_connections: [            // forbid any direct A\u2192D or B\u2192C link  \n    [0,1], [1,0], [2,1], [3,0]  \n  ]  \n  out_nodes: [0,1]  \n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]  \n  target_quantum: [                  // un-normalized 4-photon target  \n    \"0000\",   // ancilla self-click patterns heralding |\u03a6+>\u2297|\u03a6+>  \n    \"0101\",  \n    \"1010\",  \n    \"1111\"  \n  ]  \n  loss_func: \"cr\", optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", number_resolving: true  \n\nWhy this is novel and interesting:  \n  \u2022 **First photonic demonstration** of quantum network coding in the butterfly geometry via **dual, parallel entanglement-swap**\u2014no prior Pytheus design tackles this.  \n  \u2022 Uses a **single static** interferometer mesh to implement two simultaneous Bell-type measurements over crossing links, maximizing resource sharing.  \n  \u2022 Captures the core advantage of quantum network coding\u2014two independent qubit transmissions over one bottleneck\u2014offering a path to high\u2010throughput repeater nodes.  \n  \u2022 **Generalizes** easily to larger crossbar and mesh topologies by adding more pair sources and modestly enlarging the switching interferometer.  \n\nThis target firmly sits in the \u201cquantum networks\u201d domain (entanglement swapping, teleportation, network coding), is free of dynamic feedback or cavities, and is fully within Pytheus\u2019s design capabilities."

|00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) only connect to ancilla detectors [1..6], not to outputs:\n  Forbid edges [[j,0],[j,7]] for j in [1..6]\n\nTarget quantum:\n  // Conditional on exactly one click per mediator pair (post-selecting six ancilla clicks,  \n  // two from each branch combined on the internal interferometer), the state at detectors 0 and 7 is\n  ['00','11']\n\nRemarks:\n  \u2022 The internal linear-optical network must erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. This realizes a truly reconfigurable quantum\u2010network primitive in one device.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses N=4 Rydberg sites \u2192 4 single-photon emitters  \n  \u2022 Static linear-optical mixing + 6 detectors (2 outputs, 4 ancilla)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections forbid direct emitter\u2192output shortcuts  \n  \u2022 Target quantum for each heralding pattern is a Bell state on the chosen pair  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement references  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cReconfigurable Entanglement Router for Four Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites by four independent single-photon emitters A, B, C, D. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. This \u201cone-shot distil-and-swap\u201d circuit can outperform two separate steps by reducing resource overhead and losses.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses three probabilistic photon-pair sources (modeling Rydberg sites creating weak Bell pairs)  \n  \u2022 An 8-mode linear-optical network mixing the four \u201cmiddle\u201d photons for joint purification+swap  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors only, no dynamic control  \n  \u2022 Output: detectors 0 and 1 carry a purified Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 upon heralding clicks in the four ancilla detectors  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSimultaneous Entanglement Distillation and Swapping in One Static Circuit\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four Rydberg-array nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by three probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to B-input (mode 2).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits one photon to B\u2032-input (mode 3) and one to C-input (mode 4).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2083 emits one photon to C\u2032-input (mode 5) and one to node D (detector 1).\n\nThese three sources each produce imperfect Bell pairs. A static linear-optical mesh mixes the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (2,3,4,5) so that a specific four-click pattern in ancilla detectors heralds both:\n  1) Distillation of the two weak Bell pairs B\u2013C  \n  2) Entanglement swapping that projects A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Emitters (sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083) \u2192 linear-optical network mixing modes [2,3,4,5] \u2192 Detectors:\n    \u2022 Output nodes (post-selected pair): [0:A_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 Ancilla detectors: [2,3,4,5] (herald purification+swap)\n\nKey Pytheus config hints:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:\n      \u2013 forbid any source from connecting directly to both outputs: [[0,1]]  \n      \u2013 enforce S\u2081\u2192(0,2), S\u2082\u2192(3,4), S\u2083\u2192(5,1] and remove all other cross-links  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n  \u2022 no single_emitters, no loops, number_resolving = True  \n  \u2022 loss_func = 'cr', optimizer = 'L-BFGS-B\u2019, etc.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N weak links in series, designing one\u2010shot circuits that perform multi-pair distillation + swap in one go.  \n  \u2013 Apply to Rydberg arrays by mapping each weak Bell pair to two-photon excitations from adjacent atoms, with emitted photons fed into the Pytheus\u2010designed interferometer.  \n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrated distillation + swapping\u2014opens a new class of repeater primitives beyond simple sequential swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the one-shot swap-and-concentrate primitive from the ensemble. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled as independent single-photon emitters in Pytheus) with a genuinely new quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A static linear-optical network that implements a near-complete Bell-state analyzer for two photonic qubits by injecting two ancilla photons (from Rydberg emitters) and post-selecting on distinctive click patterns.  \n  2) A single circuit that simultaneously teleports two logical qubits across four Rydberg nodes in one \u201cdouble-teleportation\u201d step\u2014cross-swap of two qubits in parallel.  \n  3) A reconfigurable \u201centanglement router\u201d that, conditional on which subset of ancilla detectors clicks, entangles one of three possible remote node-pairs among four Rydberg sites in a single static interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus-feasibility:\n  1) The Bell-state analyzer is a measurement-network primitive (a transformation), not just creating a Bell pair. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It\u2019s a measurement\u2010network (a three-photon, static interferometer) that performs a non-demolition Z\u2297Z parity check on two data qubits by injecting a single ancilla photon.  All resources\u2014single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s remit; no cavities or feedback.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  Pytheus has not produced a linear-optical network for a heralded parity measurement on two qubits with minimal ancilla.  This provides a new entanglement-purification/ error-detection primitive for quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2]  (qubit A, qubit B, ancilla)  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 0  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0\u20263] for \u201ceven\u201d outcomes, [4\u20267] for \u201codd\u201d  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = map the 2\u00d72\u00d72=8 basis states |x y z\u27e9 to eight distinct output modes, grouped by parity of x\u2295y  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = forbid direct emitter\u2192wrong-parity detectors  \n  \u2022 purely static beam splitters & phase shifts + number-resolving detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Parity Analyzer for Two Qubits Using a Rydberg Ancilla Photon\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote qubit-photons (from two Rydberg atoms) as single-photon emitters Q\u2081 (emitter 0) and Q\u2082 (emitter 1), plus one ancilla photon from a third Rydberg site (emitter 2). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). To be PRL-worthy, you need a truly novel twist\u2014e.g. exploiting genuine Rydberg interactions in-circuit, achieving deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a new degree of freedom\u2014rather than a trivial parity\u2010check mapping.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs).     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2013compatible ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (as single\u2010photon emitters) with a genuinely new quantum\u2010network transformation\u2014but not mere state generation:  \n   1) A static \u201centanglement\u2010switching matrix\u201d that, post\u2010selectively, connects any two disjoint Bell pairs among four Rydberg nodes.  \n   2) A \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network: two simultaneous teleportations (A\u2192D and B\u2192C) in one static circuit, realising a photonic network\u2010coding primitive.  \n   3) A heralded nonlocal CNOT gate between two remote Rydberg nodes using two ancilla photons and post\u2010selected interferometry.  \n\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty and feasibility:  \n   1) Entanglement\u2010switching router is too close to existing multiplexed routers.  \n   2) Dual teleportation network (the butterfly) has no analogue in the explored experiments and leverages teleportation\u2014a core network primitive Pytheus has not yet tackled. It uses only pair sources, single\u2010photon inputs, beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully static, no feedback.  \n   3) Heralded nonlocal CNOT is reminiscent of the existing heralded CNOT/Toffoli gates.  \n\n  Step 3: Choose idea 2.  \n\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n   This is the first proposal to design a **simultaneous dual teleportation**\u2014a \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d\u2014in a single static linear\u2010optical circuit. It realises a network\u2010coding scenario (two senders\u2192two receivers) by two Bell\u2010state measurements at a central station, securing the first Pytheus blueprint for teleportation\u2010based network coding.  \n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:  \n   \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A_unknown, 1:B_unknown]  \n   \u2022 pair_sources S\u2081, S\u2082 produce ancilla Bell pairs  \n   \u2022 total modes = 6 photons \u2192 static interferometer \u2192 6 detectors  \n   \u2022 out_nodes = [det_C, det_D]  (the two teleported outputs)  \n   \u2022 anc_detectors = [\u03bc\u2081,\u03bc\u2082,\u03bc\u2083,\u03bc\u2084]  (the four Bell\u2010measurement clicks)  \n   \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any direct emitter\u2192output shortcuts  \n   \u2022 target: post\u2010select on one click per \u03bc\u2081\u2026\u03bc\u2084 \u2192 herald A\u2192D and B\u2192C teleportations (each up to known Pauli corrections)  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cQuantum Butterfly Teleportation Network: Simultaneous Dual Teleportation via Rydberg\u2010Array Emission\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites A and B by single-photon emitters 0 and 1, each producing an unknown qubit photon. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082 generate ancilla Bell pairs: one pair for teleporting A\u2192D, one for B\u2192C. All six photons (2 unknowns + 4 ancilla) enter a single static linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phases) and are directed to six number\u2010resolving detectors:\n\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D_C, D_D]  \n      \u2013 Detector D_C carries the teleported qubit from B (up to known correction)  \n      \u2013 Detector D_D carries the teleported qubit from A  \n\n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [\u03bc\u2081, \u03bc\u2082, \u03bc\u2083, \u03bc\u2084]  \n      \u2013 (\u03bc\u2081,\u03bc\u2082) click pattern signals the Bell measurement outcome for A\u2019s teleportation  \n      \u2013 (\u03bc\u2083,\u03bc\u2084) click pattern signals the Bell measurement outcome for B\u2019s teleportation  \n\nConstraints:\n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid emitters 0&1 from coupling directly to D_C or D_D; forbid ancilla photons from landing on D_C/D_D  \n  \u2022 number_resolving = True  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback required inside the optical network (Pauli corrections are applied externally)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: simultaneous Bell\u2010measurement projection on (A,S\u2081) and (B,S\u2082), post\u2010selecting exactly one click in each ancilla pair \u2192 transfers unknown qubits A\u2192D_D and B\u2192D_C  \n\nThis static \u201cbutterfly\u201d circuit realises a primitive of **quantum network coding** by dual teleportation. It generalises immediately to larger senders/receivers, opening up a new family of teleportation\u2010based network protocols for Rydberg\u2010array implementations."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Leveraging single-emitter probe and ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors within the PythOptics framework, our scheme implements the first photonic channel-discrimination primitive for unknown transducers without feedback control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description of target: \u201c4-Node Chain Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg\u2010Based Quantum Repeaters\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four remote Rydberg\u2010array nodes A,B,C,D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the optical circuit. We want to post-selectively entangle the qubit at A with the qubit at D by performing two back-to-back entanglement\u2010swapping measurements at the intermediate nodes B and C\u2014all within one static linear-optical network.  \n\nGeneral structure (top to bottom):  \n  Emitters: [1:A] [2:B\u2081] [3:B\u2082] [4:C\u2081] [5:C\u2082] [6:D]  \n  \u2192 beam-splitter network to distribute photons among detectors  \n  Detectors: [A_out] [D_out] [swap_B_1] [swap_B_2] [swap_C_1] [swap_C_2]  \n\nConstraints:  \n  \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending directly to both A_out & D_out  \n  \u2022 no common emitter linking A and D without going through B or C  \n  \u2022 four ancilla detection modes (swap_B_1, swap_B_2, swap_C_1, swap_C_2) herald successful two-step swapping  \n\nTarget quantum (un\u2010normalized):  \n  |00\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e + |11\u3009\u208dA,D\u208e  \n\nIn this configuration, the two-step entanglement swap is implemented in one combined interferometer. Post-selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors projects the remaining two modes (A_out, D_out) into a Bell state. This design generalizes directly to longer chains (more intermediate Rydberg nodes) with only linear increases in emitters and ancilla detectors, opening a path toward integrated photonic repeater modules for Rydberg\u2010based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially just two consecutive entanglement swaps packaged into one static interferometer\u2014a straightforward concatenation of the standard two-node swapping protocol. Both the foundational entanglement\u2010swapping experiment (Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted) and its multi\u2010swap extensions (e.g. Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs, the \u201cbutterfly\u201d four\u2010photon joint measurement, or the one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeater) already cover this construction. As a trivial chain\u2010lengthening of known schemes, it lacks the novelty required for a PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a direct concatenation of standard entanglement\u2010swapping blocks (one Bell pair swap at B, followed by another at C), a trivial extension of both the textbook two\u2010node swap and known multi\u2010swap experiments (e.g. \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d and the ensemble\u2019s butterfly\u2010network joint measurement). To be novel, you need a genuinely new twist\u2014such as non\u2010trivial superposition of swap orders, topology\u2010protected routing, or integration with an entirely new resource beyond simple chain\u2010lengthening.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cCoherent Superposition of Two-Path Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg\u2010Array Nodes\u201d\n\nWe label four remote Rydberg nodes A, B, C, D. Each node is represented by a single\u2010photon emitter in the circuit. We perform entanglement swapping between A and D by two possible mediator nodes B or C, but we erase the which\u2010mediator information by interfering their ancillary photons on a small beam\u2010splitter mesh. Post\u2010selecting on clicks in the four ancilla detectors heralds that A and D are projected into a Bell state via a coherent superposition of the two swap channels.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n Emitters:     [0:A] [1:B\u2081] [2:B\u2082] [3:C\u2081] [4:C\u2082] [5:D]  \n Setup:        Static linear\u2010optical circuit mixing modes from B and C  \n Detectors:   [0:A_out] [1:D_out] [2] [3] [4] [5]   // detectors 2\u20135 are ancilla\n\nKey constraints:\n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5]]  \n   (forbid any mediator emitter from sending to A_out or D_out)  \n \u2022 no direct source connects A and D  \n \u2022 post\u2010select four ancilla clicks to herald swap  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on detectors [0,1]\n\nThis design generalizes to more mediator nodes or hierarchical superpositions of swap\u2010channels, offering a new family of repeater\u2010like, superposed\u2010topology quantum networks implementable by Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is effectively the same primitive as an entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch or indefinite\u2010order entanglement swapping\u2014heralding A\u2013D Bell correlations via a coherent superposition of mediation through B or C. two\u2010path superposition of standard swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cThree-Branch Coherent Entanglement Swap via Rydberg-Array Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg sites by eight single-photon emitters:\n  Emitters: [0:A], [1:B\u2081], [2:B\u2082], [3:C\u2081], [4:C\u2082], [5:D\u2081], [6:D\u2082], [7:E].\n\nGoal:\nPost-selectively project the two output modes at detectors 0 and 7 into the Bell state |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only connect to their output detectors 0 and 7\n  Forbid edges [[0,i],[7,i]] for i in [1..6]\n  // Mediator emitters B\u2081\u2013D\u2082 ([1..6]) erase the path-label (which mediator) by mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While extending entanglement swapping to three parallel mediator branches may sound in a Four\u2010Node Photonic Circuit,\u201d both of which already realize coherent superpositions of multiple swap channels in one shot. Simply going from two to three branches\u2014even with Rydberg-array emitters\u2014does not introduce a qualitatively new resource or protocol, but is a trivial generalization of known multi\u2010path swap schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing multiple entanglement-swap paths already demonstrated by the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d experiments. To be PRL-worthy, you must introduce a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. non-trivial causal order beyond multi-branch superposition, integration of a novel non-linear interaction, or a topologically protected mediation mechanism\u2014not merely increase the number of swapping arms.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description:\n\u201cReconfigurable Entanglement Router for Four Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites by four independent single-photon emitters A, B, C, D. These emitters feed into a single static linear-optical network and are measured by six detectors: two \u201cclient\u201d outputs (labelled 0,1) and four \u201cancilla\u201d detectors (labelled 2\u20135).\n\nBy post-selecting on which pair of ancilla detectors clicks, the same hardware projects a different pair of emitters into a Bell state. For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While offering a useful modular repeater\u2010style component, this \u201creconfigurable entanglement router\u201d is essentially the same static, heralding\u2010pattern\u2013driven entanglement\u2010switch or router already proposed\u2014e.g. the Pythreus\u2010compatible \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d\u2014merely extended to four nodes. A static linear-optical mesh mixes the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (2,3,4,5) so that a specific four-click pattern in ancilla detectors heralds both:\n  1) Distillation of the two weak Bell pairs B\u2013C  \n  2) Entanglement swapping that projects A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Emitters (sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083) \u2192 linear-optical network mixing modes [2,3,4,5] \u2192 Detectors:\n    \u2022 Output nodes (post-selected pair): [0:A_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 Ancilla detectors: [2,3,4,5] (herald purification+swap)\n\nKey Pytheus Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc').
