LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled by single\u2010photon emitters) with a nontrivial quantum\u2010network transformation (no pure state generation):\n  1) A chain of two sequential entanglement swaps between A\u2013B and C\u2013D to link A and D (too close to existing multi\u2010swap examples).\n  2) A star/hub distribution to many leaves (tends toward GHZ generation, disallowed).\n  3) A single integrated circuit that simultaneously purifies three weak Bell pairs (A\u2013B, B\u2013C, C\u2013D) and swaps at B and C in one step, projecting A\u2013D into a high-fidelity Bell state\u2014i.e. one\u2010shot entanglement\u2010distillation + swapping.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & feasibility check:\n  \u2022 #1 is just lengthening known entanglement-swap chains.\n  \u2022 #2 drifts into multi-party state generation.\n  \u2022 #3 has no analogue in the explored list, uses only linear optics and post-selection, no feedback or cavities, purely a quantum-network primitive.\n\nStep 3: Pick #3.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  No existing Pytheus design bundles entanglement distillation and swapping into a single static interferometer. This \u201cone-shot distil-and-swap\u201d circuit can outperform two separate steps by reducing resource overhead and losses.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 Uses three probabilistic photon-pair sources (modeling Rydberg sites creating weak Bell pairs)  \n  \u2022 An 8-mode linear-optical network mixing the four \u201cmiddle\u201d photons for joint purification+swap  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors only, no dynamic control  \n  \u2022 Output: detectors 0 and 1 carry a purified Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 upon heralding clicks in the four ancilla detectors  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cSimultaneous Entanglement Distillation and Swapping in One Static Circuit\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model four Rydberg-array nodes A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by three probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n  \u2022 Source S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to B-input (mode 2).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2082 emits one photon to B\u2032-input (mode 3) and one to C-input (mode 4).  \n  \u2022 Source S\u2083 emits one photon to C\u2032-input (mode 5) and one to node D (detector 1).\n\nThese three sources each produce imperfect Bell pairs. A static linear-optical mesh mixes the four \u201cmiddle\u201d modes (2,3,4,5) so that a specific four-click pattern in ancilla detectors heralds both:\n  1) Distillation of the two weak Bell pairs B\u2013C  \n  2) Entanglement swapping that projects A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state.\n\nVisualization (top to bottom):\n  Emitters (sources S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083) \u2192 linear-optical network mixing modes [2,3,4,5] \u2192 Detectors:\n    \u2022 Output nodes (post-selected pair): [0:A_out, 1:D_out]  \n    \u2022 Ancilla detectors: [2,3,4,5] (herald purification+swap)\n\nKey Pytheus config hints:\n  \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections:\n      \u2013 forbid any source from connecting directly to both outputs: [[0,1]]  \n      \u2013 enforce S\u2081\u2192(0,2), S\u2082\u2192(3,4), S\u2083\u2192(5,1] and remove all other cross-links  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n  \u2022 no single_emitters, no loops, number_resolving = True  \n  \u2022 loss_func = 'cr', optimizer = 'L-BFGS-B\u2019, etc.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N weak links in series, designing one\u2010shot circuits that perform multi-pair distillation + swap in one go.  \n  \u2013 Apply to Rydberg arrays by mapping each weak Bell pair to two-photon excitations from adjacent atoms, with emitted photons fed into the Pytheus\u2010designed interferometer.  \n\nThis network transformation\u2014integrated distillation + swapping\u2014opens a new class of repeater primitives beyond simple sequential swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the one-shot swap-and-concentrate primitive from the ensemble. To be novel, you need a new resource or operational principle beyond combining distillation and swapping in a single post-selected linear-optical network.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d (modeled as independent single-photon emitters in Pytheus) with a genuinely new quantum-network transformation (not mere state generation):\n  1) A static linear-optical network that implements a near-complete Bell-state analyzer for two photonic qubits by injecting two ancilla photons (from Rydberg emitters) and post-selecting on distinctive click patterns.  \n  2) A single circuit that simultaneously teleports two logical qubits across four Rydberg nodes in one \u201cdouble-teleportation\u201d step\u2014cross-swap of two qubits in parallel.  \n  3) A reconfigurable \u201centanglement router\u201d that, conditional on which subset of ancilla detectors clicks, entangles one of three possible remote node-pairs among four Rydberg sites in a single static interferometer.\n\nStep 2: Evaluate novelty and Pytheus-feasibility:\n  1) The Bell-state analyzer is a measurement-network primitive (a transformation), not just creating a Bell pair. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). To be novel, you need a fundamentally new mechanism\u2014e.g. exploiting Rydberg nonlinearity in-circuit rather than treating them as simple single-photon ancillas, a deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a novel physical degree of freedom beyond standard linear optics.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It\u2019s a measurement\u2010network (a three-photon, static interferometer) that performs a non-demolition Z\u2297Z parity check on two data qubits by injecting a single ancilla photon.  All resources\u2014single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s remit; no cavities or feedback.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea (3).\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  Pytheus has not produced a linear-optical network for a heralded parity measurement on two qubits with minimal ancilla.  This provides a new entanglement-purification/ error-detection primitive for quantum networks.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [0,1,2]  (qubit A, qubit B, ancilla)  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 0  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0\u20263] for \u201ceven\u201d outcomes, [4\u20267] for \u201codd\u201d  \n  \u2022 target_quantum = map the 2\u00d72\u00d72=8 basis states |x y z\u27e9 to eight distinct output modes, grouped by parity of x\u2295y  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = forbid direct emitter\u2192wrong-parity detectors  \n  \u2022 purely static beam splitters & phase shifts + number-resolving detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cHeralded Linear-Optical Parity Analyzer for Two Qubits Using a Rydberg Ancilla Photon\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote qubit-photons (from two Rydberg atoms) as single-photon emitters Q\u2081 (emitter 0) and Q\u2082 (emitter 1), plus one ancilla photon from a third Rydberg site (emitter 2). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). To be PRL-worthy, you need a truly novel twist\u2014e.g. exploiting genuine Rydberg interactions in-circuit, achieving deterministic four-state discrimination without feed-forward, or coupling to a new degree of freedom\u2014rather than a trivial parity\u2010check mapping.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs). LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2013compatible ways to combine \u201crydberg atom array\u201d (as single\u2010photon emitters) with a genuinely new quantum\u2010network transformation\u2014but not mere state generation:  \n   1) A static \u201centanglement\u2010switching matrix\u201d that, post\u2010selectively, connects any two disjoint Bell pairs among four Rydberg nodes.  \n   2) A \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network: two simultaneous teleportations (A\u2192D and B\u2192C) in one static circuit, realising a photonic network\u2010coding primitive.  \n   3) A heralded nonlocal CNOT gate between two remote Rydberg nodes using two ancilla photons and post\u2010selected interferometry.  \n\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty and feasibility:  \n   1) Entanglement\u2010switching router is too close to existing multiplexed routers.  \n   2) Dual teleportation network (the butterfly) has no analogue in the explored experiments and leverages teleportation\u2014a core network primitive Pytheus has not yet tackled. It uses only pair sources, single\u2010photon inputs, beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully static, no feedback.  \n   3) Heralded nonlocal CNOT is reminiscent of the existing heralded CNOT/Toffoli gates.  \n\n  Step 3: Choose idea 2.  \n\n  Step 4: Novelty:  \n   This is the first proposal to design a **simultaneous dual teleportation**\u2014a \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d\u2014in a single static linear\u2010optical circuit. It realises a network\u2010coding scenario (two senders\u2192two receivers) by two Bell\u2010state measurements at a central station, securing the first Pytheus blueprint for teleportation\u2010based network coding.  \n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:  \n   \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A_unknown, 1:B_unknown]  \n   \u2022 pair_sources S\u2081, S\u2082 produce ancilla Bell pairs  \n   \u2022 total modes = 6 photons \u2192 static interferometer \u2192 6 detectors  \n   \u2022 out_nodes = [det_C, det_D]  (the two teleported outputs)  \n   \u2022 anc_detectors = [\u03bc\u2081,\u03bc\u2082,\u03bc\u2083,\u03bc\u2084]  (the four Bell\u2010measurement clicks)  \n   \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any direct emitter\u2192output shortcuts  \n   \u2022 target: post\u2010select on one click per \u03bc\u2081\u2026\u03bc\u2084 \u2192 herald A\u2192D and B\u2192C teleportations (each up to known Pauli corrections)  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cQuantum Butterfly Teleportation Network: Simultaneous Dual Teleportation via Rydberg\u2010Array Emission\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites A and B by single-photon emitters 0 and 1, each producing an unknown qubit photon.     "output": "Description:\n\u201cEntanglement Percolation on a Photonic Square via Rydberg\u2010Array Emitters\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four remote Rydberg\u2010atom sites A, B, C, D in a square.  Each adjacent pair of sites is connected by a probabilistic photonic Bell\u2010pair source: S_AB, S_BC, S_CD, S_DA.  Each source emits two photons into the network\u2014one photon toward each endpoint node.  We wish to post\u2010selectively create a high\u2010fidelity Bell link between the diagonal nodes A and C by performing **two simultaneous Bell\u2010measurements** at a central linear\u2010optical mediator on the four internal photons arriving from edges AB, BC, CD, DA.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:  S_AB  S_BC  S_CD  S_DA  \n    \u2193      \u2193      \u2193      \u2193  \n  Modes:  [A_out] [B_int1] [B_int2] [C_out] [D_int1] [D_int2] [A_int] [C_int]  \n    \u2192  Static beam\u2010splitter & phase\u2010shifter network \u2192  \n  Detectors:  \n    \u2022 Outputs: D\u2080 (A_out), D\u2081 (C_out)  \n    \u2022 Ancillas: D\u2082\u2026D\u2085 (B_int1, B_int2, D_int1, D_int2)\n\nWorkflow:\n  1) Each of S_AB \u2192 (A_out, B_int1), S_BC \u2192 (B_int2, C_out), S_CD \u2192 (C_int, D_int2), S_DA \u2192 (D_int1, A_int).  \n  2) Four \u201cinternal\u201d modes (B_int1,B_int2,D_int1,D_int2) are mixed in a single static 4-mode interferometer, then detected at D\u2082\u2026D\u2085.  \n  3) Post\u2010selecting on exactly one click in each ancilla detector heralds two simultaneous Bell\u2010projective measurements on the internal edges, thereby \u201cpercolating\u201d entanglement across the square and projecting A_out & C_out (detectors D\u2080, D\u2081) into the Bell state |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\n  \u2022 No Pytheus example has explored **entanglement percolation** on a 2\u00d72 network\u2014existing designs are limited to one\u2010dimensional chains or single swaps.  \n  \u2022 Performing two Bell\u2010measurements in parallel on a closed loop to rewire diagonal entanglement is a new network\u2010coding primitive, bridging ideas from percolation theory and quantum repeaters.\n\nWhy Pytheus can do it:\n  \u2022 Uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (no single\u2010photon feedback).  \n  \u2022 Static linear\u2010optical elements (beam splitters, phase shifters).  \n  \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors with post\u2010selection\u2014no dynamic control or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Abstract 2-dimensional modes (no hyper-/hybrid-entanglement needed).\n\nPytheus config sketch:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement percolation on a square network via simultaneous dual\u2010swap measurements\",\n  num_pre: 1,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  single_emitters: [],                  // we use 4 probabilistic pair\u2010sources\n  pair_sources: [\"S_AB\",\"S_BC\",\"S_CD\",\"S_DA\"],\n  out_nodes: [0,1],                     // detectors D\u2080, D\u2081 \u2192 A_out, C_out\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],             // detectors for B_int1,B_int2,D_int1,D_int2\n  removed_connections: [\n    // forbid any source directly linking both outputs:\n    [\"S_AB\",[1]], [\"S_BC\",[0]], [\"S_CD\",[0]], [\"S_DA\",[1]]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],          // unnormalized Bell state on [0,1]\n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\"\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 Extend to larger 2D lattices (triangles, hexagons) to study percolation thresholds.  \n  \u2022 Replace diagonal percolation with multi\u2010path routing\u2014design a family of heralded \u201cmesh\u2010routing\u201d interferometers.  \n  \u2022 Map the same network onto multi\u2010frequency or multi\u2010temporal modes for multiplexed repeater architectures.\n\nThis proposal offers a fresh class of quantum\u2010network transformations\u2014**entanglement percolation modules**\u2014suitable for Phys.Rev.Lett. theory and ripe for Pytheus\u2010driven experimental design."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Eavesdropper localization for quantum and classical channels via\n  nonlinear scattering\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Quantum and semi--quantum key distribution in networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Reducing the number of single-photon detectors in quantum key\n  distribution networks by time multiplexing\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': A three-branch \u201centanglement\u2010switch\u201d provides a new quantum\u2010network primitive\u2014indefinite\u2010mediator swapping with higher\u2010order superposition.\n\n  Step 5: |00>+|11> via a coherent superposition of swapping through mediators B, C, or D.\n\nConfiguration:\n  \u2022 num_pre: 1  \n  \u2022 num_anc (ancilla detectors): 6  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: [0\u20267]  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2,3,4,5,6]  // detectors for mediator photons  \n  \u2022 out_nodes (Bell outputs): [0,7]  \n\nRemoved connections:\n  // A (emitter 0) and E (emitter 7) only mixing all six mediator photons in a 3-port tritter-like arrangement, so that the final heralding cannot distinguish B vs C vs D.\n  \u2022 Upon the heralding pattern (six clicks), detectors 0 and 7 collapse into a maximally entangled qubit pair.\n  \u2022 This fully static circuit generalizes to N-branch superpositions by adding more mediator emitter pairs and extending the mixing network, yielding a family of \u201cmulti-branch entanglement-switch\u201d modules for Rydberg-based quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of superposing For example:\n \u2013 If ancilla detectors [2,3] fire, the network entangles emitters A & B \u2192 clients at detectors 0,1 in |00>+|11>.  \n \u2013 If ancilla [2,4] fire, it entangles A & C, etc.  \n \u2013 In general there are six possible ancilla-pairs, giving all six distinct two-node entanglement links among A, B, C, D.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0:A, 1:B, 2:C, 3:D]  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,1]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [2,3,4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections = forbid any emitter \u2192 output detector except the two chosen by each heralded pattern  \n \u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] on [0,1]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 4  \n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Simply permute labels on emitters and ancilla detectors to realize any of the six client-pairs, yielding a family of \u201csoftware-defined\u201d entanglement links.  \n  \u2013 Scale to more nodes by adding more emitters + ancillas and an expanded interferometric mesh.  \n\nThis device demonstrates a new primitive in quantum networks\u2014a single static \u201centanglement switch/router\u201d implementable with Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core primitive\u2014one static interferometer where different ancilla detector click pairs herald which two nodes become Bell\u2010entangled\u2014already appears in the ensemble\u2019s multiplexed quantum entanglement router. It uses only single-photon emitters, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no feedback\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities\u2014and I do not see a prior Pytheus design for a three-state unambiguous Bell measurement.  \n  2) Double-teleportation would require dynamic feed-forward corrections to route two qubits simultaneously\u2014Pytheus cannot design that.  \n  3) The conditional router is close to existing \u201centanglement switch\u201d ideas and was flagged as insufficiently novel.\n\nStep 3: The most promising is idea #1: a near-complete Bell-state analyzer using ancilla photons.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has tackled the design of a static linear-optical network that unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states by injecting two ancilla photons. Standard linear optics without ancillas can only distinguish two; with ancillas one can in principle reach three, but an explicit interferometric layout with minimal resources has not been generated by Pytheus before.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2022 We only need four single-photon emitters (two for the qubit pair to be measured + two Rydberg-mode ancillas).  \n  \u2022 A purely static beam-splitter/phase-shifter network that mixes these four photons and routes them to six number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no feedback loops.  \n  \u2022 Post-selected detection patterns herald unambiguous identification of three Bell states; the fourth remains inconclusive.  \n  \u2022 It is a measurement-network transformation (Bell-measurement), not state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cStatic Linear-Optical Three-State Bell-State Analyzer Using Rydberg-Array Ancillas\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two input qubits (in an unknown Bell state) by single-photon emitters Q\u2081 and Q\u2082, and we supply two ancilla single photons from separate Rydberg sites A and B. All four photons enter a fixed network of beam splitters and phase shifters, and are directed to six number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085. By post-selecting on exactly four clicks\u2014two clicks occurring on designated \u201cancilla detectors\u201d and two on the \u201cinput detectors\u201d\u2014we obtain three distinct click-patterns that each unambiguously signal one of three Bell states (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9, |\u03c8\u207b\u27e9, |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9). Any other click pattern is discarded (inconclusive for |\u03a6\u207b\u27e9).  \n\nConfiguration outline:\n  \u2022 single_emitters = [Q1,Q2,A,B]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [D0,D1]   (where the two input photons would land)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [D2,D3,D4,D5]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: forbid any emitter from directly coupling only to D0,D1 (to ensure mixing)  \n  \u2022 target_mapping: three disjoint sets of four-click outcomes \u2192 {Bell state label}\n\nThis circuit realizes a near-complete Bell measurement\u2014a key primitive for teleportation, entanglement swapping and MDI-QKD\u2014using only static linear optics and two Rydberg-sourced ancilla photons. It immediately generalizes to higher success probability or to four-state discrimination by adding more ancillas and a slightly larger interferometer, opening a new family of measurement-based quantum network protocols accessible to Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Existing ancilla-photon Bell analyzers already achieve three-state discrimination via static interferometers (see Grice PRA 84, 042331 or the ensemble\u2019s bound-state analyzer). All three photons enter a fixed interferometric network of beam splitters and phase shifters and then impinge on eight number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2087. We choose the mapping:\n\n\u2022 Input basis states S_even = { |00z\u27e9, |11z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2083  \n\u2022 Input basis states S_odd  = { |01z\u27e9, |10z\u27e9 } for z\u2208{0,1} \u2192 detectors D\u2084\u2026D\u2087  \n\nThe network is optimized so that each of the eight computational basis states is routed to a unique detector. By grouping detectors 0\u20133 as \u201ceven\u201d and 4\u20137 as \u201codd,\u201d a click in one of those four detectors unambiguously heralds the Z\u2297Z parity outcome of the two qubits without measuring them directly.  \n\nPytheus-config hints:\n  single_emitters = [0,1,2]  \n  num_anc = 0  \n  out_nodes = [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7]  \n  removed_connections = [\n    // forbid Q\u2081 or Q\u2082 from sending to detectors in the opposite parity block\n    [0,[4,5,6,7]], [1,[4,5,6,7]],\n    [0,[ ],],[1,[ ],] // etc.\n  ]  \n  target_quantum = ['000','001','010','011','100','101','110','111']  \n                   mapped to detectors [0\u20267] respectively  \n\nNo dynamic feedback or cavities are used\u2014only single-photon sources, static linear optics, and photon\u2010number detectors.  This measurement primitive can be immediately applied to entanglement purification, measurement\u2010device-independent QKD, and distributed error detection in Rydberg-based quantum networks\u2014and generalizes to N-qubit parity checks by adding more ancilla photons and detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Two-qubit parity checks via static linear optics and ancilla photons are well-explored (see KLM\u2010style parity gates, nonlocal XOR, 4-body stabilizer readout). It remains purely a network transformation (two Bell sources to one partially entangled pair), uses only single-photon emitters + linear optics + number-resolving detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Idea 2 would require dynamic feed-forward to switch between swap vs. teleportation\u2014beyond Pytheus\u2019s static framework.  \n  \u2022 Idea 3 moves toward GHZ-like operations (state gen), so it\u2019s disallowed.\n\nStep 3: Choose idea 1: Tunable Partial Entanglement Swapping.\n\nStep 4: Novelty:\nNo previous Pytheus experiment implements a **continuously tunable** entanglement-swap measurement using ancilla photons to interpolate between no-swap (identity) and full-swap (Bell measurement). This opens a new family of repeater primitives that trade entanglement fidelity against heralding rate.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility:\n  \u2022 single_emitters: two probabilistic pair sources for the \u201cdata\u201d Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D) **plus** two single-photon emitters (rydberg ancillas)  \n  \u2022 purely static beam-splitters & phase-shifters (the tunable phase \u03b8 encodes the measurement basis)  \n  \u2022 number-resolving detectors only, post-selection on a four-click ancilla pattern  \n  \u2022 no dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hyper-entanglement, only abstract 2-dimensional modes\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\n\u201cTunable Partial Entanglement Swapping via Rydberg-Ancilla Photons\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources S\u2081 and S\u2082:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits one photon to node A (detector 0) and one to mode 1 (B-leg)  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits one photon to mode 2 (C-leg) and one to node D (detector 3)\n\nIn addition, two \u201crydberg\u201d single-photon emitters provide ancilla photons in modes 4 and 5. All four ancilla/data modes 1,2,4,5 enter a static interferometer whose internal beam-splitter reflectivities and phase shifts are set by an angle \u03b8.\n\nDetectors:\n  \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3]  (final data qubits A and D)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2,4,5]  (heralding modes)\n\nRemoved connections:\n  \u2022 forbid any direct emitter \u2192 both data output detectors: \n    removed_connections = [[S\u2081,3],[S\u2082,0],[anc\u2081,0],[anc\u2081,3],[anc\u2082,0],[anc\u2082,3]]\n  \u2022 this ensures no direct A\u2013D link\n\nTarget transformation:\n  Post-select on exactly one click in each ancilla detector.  The joint projective measurement performed on modes 1,2,4,5 implements the two-qubit measurement with POVM elements\n    M_\u03b8 = { |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a6\u207a|,  cos\u03b8|\u03a8\u207a\u27e9+sin\u03b8|\u03a8\u207b\u27e9 }\n\n  On the \u201csuccess\u201d pattern the remaining modes 0 and 3 collapse into a **partially entangled state**:\n    |\u03c8_out(\u03b8)\u27e9 \u221d cos\u03b8 |00\u27e9 + sin\u03b8 |11\u27e9\n\nPytheus config hints:\n  {\n    description: \"Tunable partial entanglement swapping\",\n    single_emitters: [],        // we use 2 probabilistic pairs + 2 ancillas\n    num_anc: 4,\n    out_nodes: [0,3],\n    anc_detectors: [1,2,4,5],\n    removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,3],[2,0],[4,0],[5,0],[5,3]],  \n    target_quantum: [ // un\u2010normalized amplitudes for modes [0,3] conditional on ancilla clicks\n      \"00\",      // amplitude \u221d cos\u03b8\n      \"\",        // no cross terms\n      \"\", \n      \"11\"       // amplitude \u221d sin\u03b8\n    ],\n    parameters: { theta: \"phase in internal network\" },\n    number_resolving: true,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    loss_func: \"cr\"\n  }\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 By varying \u03b8, one continuously interpolates between no-swap (\u03b8=0, identity) and full Bell swap (\u03b8=\u03c0/4).  \n  \u2022 The same hardware can be retuned or reoptimized for different swap angles.  \n  \u2022 Extend to multi-hop chains by concatenating such tunable modules.  \n\nThis circuit introduces a new **partial-swap** primitive for quantum repeater nodes\u2014enabling a systematic study of fidelity vs. rate in entanglement distribution\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optical, post-selected design capabilities.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Tunable generation of non\u2010maximally entangled states via adjustable beam\u2010splitter parameters has already been demonstrated (see the PT\u2010symmetric non\u2010unitary Bell projector and linear\u2010optical partial-SWAP gate designs).     "output": "Description:\n\u201cHeralded Optical Entanglement\u2010Catalysis Between Three Rydberg Nodes\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nWe model three remote Rydberg\u2010array sites A, B and C via two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources that initially distribute Bell pairs AB and BC, plus two single\u2010photon \u201cancilla\u201d emitters at B.  A single static linear\u2010optical circuit mixes the four modes at B (the two \u201chalf\u2010pairs\u201d and two ancillas) and routes all six photons to detectors.  By post-selecting on exactly one click at each of the two ancilla detectors, the network implements the LOCC transformation\n\n  (|\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dAB\u208e \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dBC\u208e)  \u2192  |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dAC\u208e \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dB\u2081B\u2082\u208e\n\ni.e. it \u201ccatalyzes\u201d entanglement from AB\u2192AC while leaving the BC pair (the catalyst) intact.  This is achieved entirely by static beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities.\n\nVisualization (mode labels \u2192 detector labels):\n\n Emitters:  \n   \u2022 S\u2081 produces modes 0 (A) & 1 (B\u2081)  \n   \u2022 S\u2082 produces modes 2 (B\u2082) & 3 (C)  \n   \u2022 Ancilla emitters produce modes 4 & 5 at B\n\n Static interferometer mixes modes [1,2,4,5]  \n\n Detectors:  \n   \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3,1,2]  (remaining photons at A,C,B\u2081,B\u2082)  \n   \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5]   (heralding clicks)\n\nKey Pytheus hints:\n \u2022 pair_sources = [[0,1],[2,3]]  \n \u2022 single_emitters = [4,5]  \n \u2022 num_anc = 2  \n \u2022 out_nodes = [0,3,1,2]  \n \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5]  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid any source sending to unintended detectors:\n     \u2013 S\u2081\u2192[2,3,4,5], S\u2082\u2192[0,1,4,5], ancillas\u2192[0,1,2,3]  \n \u2022 target_quantum on outputs [0,3,1,2] (A,C,B\u2081,B\u2082) = \n     ['0000','0110','1001','1111']  (\u239c\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dAC\u208e\u2297\u239c\u03a6\u207a\u27e9\u208dB\u2081B\u2082\u208e)  \n \u2022 number_resolving = True\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:\nPytheus has so far produced entanglement\u2010swapping and gate\u2010teleportation circuits, but never a protocol that uses ancilla photons to **catalytically** relocate entanglement without consuming the initial BC pair.  This opens a new class of **entanglement\u2010catalysis** network transformations\u2014probabilistic, heralded LOCC operations beyond pure swapping or teleportation.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible:\nAll resources are within Pytheus\u2019s static framework: two probabilistic pair sources, two single\u2010photon emitters (Rydberg ancillas), a fixed linear-optical circuit, and number-resolving detectors.  No dynamic feed-forward or specialized nonlinearities are required.  The scheme generalizes immediately to longer catalyst chains or multi-node catalytic networks."
